Fergus is a very nice and cheerful person, you can always exchange a word, a sentence, many sentences and even talk hours about whisky with him. He conducts lectures, tastings and trainings, promoting the Duncan Taylor brand around the world. All three! Firstly, I love whisky. To be a brand ambassador means that I have to have a passion for it. And finally it can be hard work. Before the Coronavirus, at times I would leave my house at 03.00am to go to the airport to fly somewhere in Europe and then have an evening event that could last until midnight! Doing that day after day gets hard at my age. When I was about 7 years old, I went to watch a rugby match with my father. It was in February and freezing cold. He gave me a drink of whisky from his hip-flask to warm me up. I canâ€™t remember if I liked it, but it certainly did warm me! When I worked for William Grant and Sons, I was looking after a film crew that were shooting about a 50 year old that Balvenie were releasing. David Stewart, the Balvenie malt master, and Sam Simmons, the then Global brand ambassador, opened the 1962 cask on its 50th birthday, and I was standing behind the camera! So I got to taste it in Balvenie warehouse 24! An amazing experience. ğŸ˜Š For me, the most important thing is, what is the whisky like on the palate. I can put up with a whisky having a poor aroma on the nose and a short finish, as long as it is great on the palate. When I was younger, I used to love big heavy first fill Sherry bombs. But now that I am older and more experienced, I am more drawn to refill bourbon casks as they let the distillery character shine. As for flavour, I am constantly surprised at the range of flavours that you can find in whisky. No other spirit can match the variety. 5. Do not mix whisky with â€¦? Controversial views on whisky, what do you think about it? It all depends on the whisky. For me the only rule is that if you like it, drink it! In the summer, if it is hot, I have no problems in drinking a cheaper, light, everyday whisky with ice. An uncomplicated Bourbon can be fine with a splash of cola. I have seen asians drinking extremely old and rare whiskies with fizzy green tea! That it something that I would never do with an old choice whisky. But it is their own whisky, so although I would not do it, I cannot say that they canâ€™t. Working with Duncan Taylor, I have become so used to drinking whisky at cask strength, it has to be an exceptional whisky for me to enjoy it at 40%. As for water, it depends on the whisky. I will always taste a new whisky without and with water. With water the whisky can change. Sometimes it is better with water, but mostly better without. I have no rules about whisky, just enjoy it. This is impossible to answer. I am lucky to have tasted so many wonderful whiskies. The Glendronach 1968 released in 2002 to celebrate the reopening. The Lagavulin 1985/2007 21 year old. The Brora 1972/1995 22 year old â€œRare maltsâ€. Our Tomintoul 1969 45 year old Tantalus. Caperdonich 1972. Glenfiddich 1937. Some of the Karuizawa â€œNohâ€ series. Seriously, how can I choose between these! It has to be the Macallan 1940 Wooden box â€red Stripe, red waxâ€ Rinaldi import for Italy. Bottled in about 1980. As it was distilled during war time, so it is a peated Macallan. I have tasted the Speymalt Macallan 1945 from Gordon and MacPhail, but it was bottled in 2013 as a 68 year old and was too â€œwoodyâ€ it would be nice to taste something that was bottled a little earlier in its prime. I am partial to a classic â€œBlood and Sandâ€ Until recently, whisky had been in one of the longest sales booms in its history. I think that the current health crisos will see some scaling back. When things start to get better, I think that many people will not see a 1000 zÅ‚oty bottle of whisky as a priority. They will have many other things to worry about. Having said that, I see many of the newer distillleries around the world taking a new look at how they produce their spirit. As they are marketing most of their products at a younger age. Many of the large established companies have treated whisky as a commodity, making it harder to distinguish between each distilleries output. They are prducing too much bland standard whisky, and focussing on the casks. While the overall higher standards in wood is welcome, there are many other variables to look at. For example there are only about 4 different yeast strains commonly used by the major producers. Whereas in the old days, each distillery had its own strain of yeast. A renewal of focus on things such as yeast and type of barley is to be welcomed I drink wine and beer as well as whisky. In Poland you have a wide variety of great local products. You have high quality vodkas and Starka as well. Great beers, not just the more common types, but regional products such as Piwo kozicowe. You also have a huge range of traditional nalewki such as Deptucha, Miodunka, and Nalewka Orzechowa For me, the book that I always enjoy and is a great resource, is The Schweppes Guide to Scotch by Philip Morrice. It was a 1983 publication that dicusses the industry at that time, it contains details of the companies operating then and their brands. History and production information is included too. A book that was considered to have been well ahead of its time. My advice is always to buy what you enjoy drinking. Yes some people invest in whisky and make a profit. I have never done so. I do have older bottles that are now worth a large amount, but they have always been things that I drink. I have no interest in reselling them. As a company, we also bottle single cask rums. These are very different from the highly sugared mainstream products. They have a wide range of flavour profiles and are my main whisky alternative.
